parenting_scripts.title: Bedtime Meltdown
parenting_scripts.scenario: Child is screaming, crying, or having a full tantrum when it's time for bed

strategies.name: Validation + Boundary
script: You're really upset about bedtime. I can see this feels hard for you.
AND bedtime is still happening. Your body needs sleep to grow strong.
Would you like to walk to your room or would you like me to carry you gently?
I'm going to stay right here with you while you have these big feelings.
strategies.mantra: This is temporary. Their big feelings don't mean I'm doing something wrong. Consistency is kindness.
strategies.why_it_works: Acknowledging the child's emotions while maintaining the boundary shows them their feelings are valid, but the expectation remains. Offering choices gives them control within your structure.

strategies.name: Playful Approach
script: Oh no! It looks like the bedtime monster got you! The bedtime monster makes kids feel SO upset about sleep.
I wonder... should we march to bed like soldiers or hop like bunnies?
Your stuffed animals are probably wondering where you are. Should we go tell them a bedtime story?
Even when you're upset, I still love you. Let's get your body ready for sleep.
strategies.mantra: This is temporary. Their big feelings don't mean I'm doing something wrong. Consistency is kindness.
strategies.why_it_works: Playfulness can shift the emotional state and make cooperation more likely. It maintains the boundary while reducing power struggles through connection.

strategies.name: Limited Choices
script: I can see bedtime feels overwhelming right now.
You get to choose: pajamas first or teeth brushing first?
Would you like your door open a crack or closed tonight?
Your body is going to bed now, and you can choose to make it easy or hard for yourself.
strategies.mantra: This is temporary. Their big feelings don't mean I'm doing something wrong. Consistency is kindness.
strategies.why_it_works: Offering choices within the non-negotiable boundary gives children a sense of autonomy and control, making them more likely to cooperate.

parenting_scripts.title: Sibling Toy Fight
parenting_scripts.scenario: Two children are fighting, grabbing, or screaming over the same toy

strategies.name: Sportscaster Approach
script: I see two kids who both want the same toy. That's frustrating!
I'm not going to decide who gets it. You both want it, and that makes sense.
The toy is going to take a break until you both can figure out a solution together.
When you're ready to problem-solve, I'm here to help you brainstorm ideas.
strategies.mantra: I don't need to solve this FOR them. I can help them solve it together.
strategies.why_it_works: Refusing to pick sides prevents you from becoming the referee and teaches kids to work together. Taking the toy away removes the immediate trigger while they regulate.

strategies.name: Empathy for Both
script: Sarah, you're upset because you want the doll. Jake, you're upset because you had it first.
Both of your feelings make total sense to me.
Here's what's going to happen: I'm going to set a timer for 2 minutes. You can each think of ideas.
Then we'll come back together and you can share your solutions.
strategies.mantra: I don't need to solve this FOR them. I can help them solve it together.
strategies.why_it_works: Validating both children's perspectives helps them feel heard and reduces the intensity of the conflict. Giving them time to think promotes problem-solving skills.

strategies.name: Immediate Safety
script: I see hands grabbing and voices yelling. Bodies need to be safe.
Sarah, you come with me to the kitchen. Jake, you stay here in the living room.
When everyone is calm, we'll talk about the toy.
Right now, my job is to keep everyone safe.
strategies.mantra: I don't need to solve this FOR them. I can help them solve it together.
strategies.why_it_works: Physical separation prevents escalation and gives both children space to regulate their emotions before attempting problem-solving.

parenting_scripts.title: School Morning Refusal
parenting_scripts.scenario: Child is refusing to get dressed, hiding, or melting down about going to school

strategies.name: Acknowledge + Action
script: Your body is telling me that something about school feels hard today.
AND school is still happening. Let's get your body ready to go.
You can get dressed yourself, or I can help you get dressed. You choose.
We're leaving in 5 minutes. I believe you can do this.
strategies.mantra: Their resistance doesn't mean I should give in. Structure feels safe even when they fight it.
strategies.why_it_works: Validating their feelings while moving forward with the plan shows them you can handle their big emotions and still keep them safe with routines.

strategies.name: Connect First
script: Come here, kiddo. I can see this morning feels big and hard.
Tell me what's going on in your brain about school today.
That sounds really [hard/scary/frustrating]. I get it.
Even when school feels hard, I know you can handle it. Let's get ready together.
strategies.mantra: Their resistance doesn't mean I should give in. Structure feels safe even when they fight it.
strategies.why_it_works: Connection before direction helps children feel understood and supported, making them more willing to cooperate with necessary tasks.

strategies.name: Playful Power
script: Oh no! It looks like your clothes are trying to hide from you!
Should we catch that sneaky shirt? I think it went behind the door!
I wonder if your backpack is ready for an adventure today...
Your strong body is going to have a day at school, and I'll be here when you get home.
strategies.mantra: Their resistance doesn't mean I should give in. Structure feels safe even when they fight it.
strategies.why_it_works: Playfulness can transform resistance into cooperation by making necessary tasks feel like games rather than demands.

parenting_scripts.title: "I Hate You!" Outburst
parenting_scripts.scenario: Child screams "I hate you!" or "You're not my friend!" during a conflict

strategies.name: Stay Calm + Reflect
script: You're so mad at me right now. You wish I would change my mind.
It's okay to be angry with me. I can handle your big feelings.
Even when you're mad at me, I still love you completely.
When you're ready, I'm here. The answer is still [boundary].
strategies.mantra: They don't actually hate me. This is their immature brain trying to get control. I can stay steady.
strategies.why_it_works: Staying calm in the face of hurtful words models emotional regulation and shows them their big feelings can't push you away or change your boundaries.

strategies.name: Name the Feeling
script: Wow, those are some really big, angry feelings coming out of your body.
You're so frustrated that you want me to know with your biggest words.
I hear you. You wish things were different right now.
I love you even when you're angry. Even when you use those words.
strategies.mantra: They don't actually hate me. This is their immature brain trying to get control. I can stay steady.
strategies.why_it_works: Naming emotions helps children understand what they're feeling and teaches them that all feelings are acceptable, even when expressed imperfectly.

strategies.name: Empathy Bridge
script: You know what? Sometimes I feel really frustrated with people I love too.
When you say you hate me, I think you mean you hate what I'm asking you to do.
I get it. This rule feels really unfair to you right now.
And I still love you. And the rule is still the rule.
strategies.mantra: They don't actually hate me. This is their immature brain trying to get control. I can stay steady.
strategies.why_it_works: Sharing your own experience with similar feelings helps children feel less alone and shows them that strong emotions are normal and manageable.

parenting_scripts.title: Doctor Visit Anxiety
parenting_scripts.scenario: Child is crying, clinging, or refusing to cooperate at a medical appointment

strategies.name: Validation + Partnership
script: Your body feels scared about being here. Doctor visits can feel really big.
I'm going to stay right next to you the whole time.
We're a team. You don't have to be brave alone.
After this, we're going to [specific plan]. You can look forward to that.
strategies.mantra: Their fear is real and valid. I can be their calm in this storm.
strategies.why_it_works: Providing information reduces anxiety by making the unknown known. Staying physically close activates their attachment system and helps them feel safe.

strategies.name: Control + Information
script: Let me tell you exactly what's going to happen so your brain can get ready.
First [step 1], then [step 2]. I'll be holding your hand.
You get to choose: do you want to sit on my lap or on the table?
If you need to cry or squeeze my hand, that's totally okay.
strategies.mantra: Their fear is real and valid. I can be their calm in this storm.
strategies.why_it_works: Detailed information helps reduce anxiety by eliminating unknowns. Offering choices gives them some control in a situation where they feel powerless.

strategies.name: Coping Tools
script: Let's take three deep breaths together. In through your nose, out through your mouth.
I want you to look at me and think about [favorite comfort item/memory].
You can hold my hand as tight as you need to.
This will be over soon, and then we'll [comfort activity].
strategies.mantra: Their fear is real and valid. I can be their calm in this storm.
strategies.why_it_works: Teaching specific coping strategies gives children tools they can use to manage anxiety in this and future situations.

parenting_scripts.title: Transition Defiance
parenting_scripts.scenario: Child refuses to stop current activity for transition (leaving park, turning off TV, ending playtime)

strategies.name: Time + Choice
script: I can see you're not ready to stop yet. This activity is really fun for you.
We have 2 more minutes. You can use that time however you want.
When the timer goes off, we're leaving. You can walk to the car or I can carry you.
It's hard to stop fun things. And we're still going to stop.
strategies.mantra: Transitions are hard for kids. Staying consistent helps them trust the structure.
strategies.why_it_works: Acknowledging their disappointment while maintaining the boundary teaches them that feelings are valid but don't control actions. Advance notice helps their brain prepare.

strategies.name: Emotional Validation
script: You wish you could play forever. That makes total sense to me.
It's disappointing when fun things have to end.
You can be sad about leaving AND we're still leaving now.
I'll remember how much you loved this for next time.
strategies.mantra: Transitions are hard for kids. Staying consistent helps them trust the structure.
strategies.why_it_works: Validating disappointment helps children feel understood while learning that they can have feelings and still follow through with necessary actions.

strategies.name: Future Focus
script: I know it's hard to leave. Let's talk about what we're going to do next.
After we leave here, we're going to [next activity].
And tomorrow/later we can [plan for return/similar activity].
Right now your body needs to come with me, even if your feelings aren't ready.
strategies.mantra: Transitions are hard for kids. Staying consistent helps them trust the structure.
strategies.why_it_works: Focusing on what comes next helps shift their attention from what they're losing to what they're gaining, making transitions easier.

parenting_scripts.title: Physical Aggression
parenting_scripts.scenario: Child hits, bites, kicks, or throws things when upset

strategies.name: Immediate Safety
script: I won't let you hit. Bodies need to be safe.
I'm going to move your body/myself so everyone stays safe.
You have big feelings AND hitting isn't okay.
When your body is calm, we can talk about what happened.
strategies.mantra: This behavior is communication, not manipulation. They need my help learning better ways to express themselves.
strategies.why_it_works: Stopping the behavior immediately while validating the emotion teaches them that all feelings are okay, but not all actions are okay. Offering alternatives gives them appropriate outlets.

strategies.name: Feeling + Boundary
script: You're so angry your body wants to hit. I get that.
AND I'm not going to let you hurt me or anyone else.
Your angry feelings are okay. Hitting is not okay.
Let's find a safe way for your body to show those big feelings.
strategies.mantra: This behavior is communication, not manipulation. They need my help learning better ways to express themselves.
strategies.why_it_works: Separating feelings from actions helps children understand that emotions are always acceptable, but behaviors have limits and consequences.

strategies.name: Redirect Energy
script: I can see your body has lots of big energy that wants to come out.
You can hit this pillow, stomp your feet, or squeeze your hands really tight.
Your feelings are important AND people's bodies need to stay safe.
I'm going to help you find a way to get those feelings out safely.
strategies.mantra: This behavior is communication, not manipulation. They need my help learning better ways to express themselves.
strategies.why_it_works: Providing physical outlets for big emotions helps children learn appropriate ways to release intense feelings while keeping everyone safe.

parenting_scripts.title: Grocery Store Meltdown
parenting_scripts.scenario: Child has a tantrum in public, attracting stares and making shopping impossible

strategies.name: Strategic Exit
script: I can see this is really overwhelming for you right now.
We're going to take a break outside where it's quieter.
You can have your feelings, and we need to keep everyone safe.
When you're ready, we can decide together if we continue shopping or come back later.
strategies.mantra: Other people's opinions don't matter. My child needs my calm presence right now.
strategies.why_it_works: Removing overwhelming stimuli helps children regulate. Public spaces can be overstimulating, and a change of environment often helps reset their nervous system.

strategies.name: Stay and Support
script: You're having such big feelings right now. I'm right here with you.
I can see you really wanted [item]. It's disappointing when we can't have what we want.
I'm going to stay close while you have these feelings.
When you're ready, we can finish our shopping together.
strategies.mantra: This is temporary. I'm teaching them they're safe to have big emotions with me.
strategies.why_it_works: Staying present shows the child they're not alone in their big emotions. It models that feelings are manageable and temporary.

strategies.name: Distraction + Redirect
script: Wow, look how upset your body is! That's some really big energy.
I wonder... can you help me find the red apples? I need someone with good eyes.
You're still upset AND you can help me with this important job.
Thank you for helping me even when your feelings are big.
strategies.mantra: Sometimes giving them a job helps them feel important and shifts their focus.
strategies.why_it_works: Redirecting to a helpful task can shift focus from the upset to feeling useful and important, while validating their emotions.

parenting_scripts.title: Car Seat Refusal
parenting_scripts.scenario: Child refuses to get in car seat, arches back, or fights the safety straps

strategies.name: Safety First
script: Your body is saying no to the car seat. I hear that.
AND my job is to keep you safe. Car seats keep bodies safe in cars.
I'm going to help you get buckled in. You can be upset while I do my job.
As soon as you're safe, we can talk about what's making this hard.
strategies.mantra: Safety is not negotiable. I can be firm AND loving.
strategies.why_it_works: Clear boundaries around safety while acknowledging their feelings shows them that some things are non-negotiable, but you still care about their emotions.

strategies.name: Choice Within Safety
script: The car seat is happening because I need to keep you safe.
You get to choose: Would you like to climb in yourself or would you like me to help you?
Would you like to hold [comfort item] or choose our driving music?
Your body goes in the seat, and you can choose how to make it more comfortable.
strategies.mantra: I can give choices within the non-negotiable boundary.
strategies.why_it_works: Offering choices within the safety requirement gives them some control while maintaining the boundary. It helps them feel less powerless.

strategies.name: Connection First
script: Come here first. I can see you really don't want to get in your seat.
Tell me what's hard about the car seat today.
That makes sense. [Validate their concern].
I still need to keep you safe, and now I understand better how you're feeling.
strategies.mantra: Understanding their perspective doesn't mean changing the boundary.
strategies.why_it_works: Taking time to understand their resistance often reveals specific concerns (discomfort, wanting independence) that can be addressed while maintaining safety.

parenting_scripts.title: Homework Battles
parenting_scripts.scenario: Child melts down, refuses to start, or has emotional outbursts about homework

strategies.name: Break It Down
script: This homework feels really big and overwhelming to your brain right now.
Let's look at it together and break it into tiny pieces.
You don't have to do ALL of it right now. Just one small part.
I believe your brain can handle this when we make it smaller.
strategies.mantra: Big tasks feel impossible to kids. I can help them see it's manageable.
strategies.why_it_works: Overwhelming tasks trigger the fight-or-flight response. Breaking work into smaller chunks makes it feel achievable and reduces anxiety.

strategies.name: Emotional First Aid
script: Your body is telling me this feels really hard right now.
Let's take care of your big feelings first, then we'll tackle the homework.
Sometimes our brains need a break before they can learn new things.
When you're feeling calmer, your brain will be ready to work.
strategies.mantra: Learning can't happen when they're emotionally flooded. Feelings first, then academics.
strategies.why_it_works: When children are in emotional distress, their prefrontal cortex (learning brain) goes offline. Emotional regulation must come before academic work.

strategies.name: Partnership Approach
script: This homework is your job, and I'm here to support you.
What part feels hardest to you? Let's start with something easier.
I'm not going to do it for you, but I'll sit nearby while you work.
You're capable of figuring this out. I'm here if you need help.
strategies.mantra: I'm their coach, not their replacement. They need to build confidence in their own abilities.
strategies.why_it_works: Taking over homework robs children of the opportunity to build resilience and problem-solving skills. Support without rescue builds confidence.

parenting_scripts.title: Morning Routine Chaos
parenting_scripts.scenario: Child is slow, distracted, or melting down during morning routine

strategies.name: Calm Urgency
script: I can see you're moving slowly this morning. Sometimes our bodies feel sluggish.
We need to leave in 10 minutes. That's enough time if we focus.
What's the most important thing you need to do right now?
I'm going to help you stay on track without rushing your body.
strategies.mantra: I can be calm AND keep us moving. Panic makes everything harder.
strategies.why_it_works: Modeling calm urgency instead of frantic rushing helps children focus better and reduces morning stress for everyone.

strategies.name: Choice Sequence
script: You have three things left: getting dressed, eating breakfast, and brushing teeth.
Which one do you want to do first?
Great choice. After that, you can pick what comes next.
You're in charge of the order, and all three need to happen before we leave.
strategies.mantra: Giving them control over the sequence helps them feel empowered while everything still gets done.
strategies.why_it_works: Children resist being controlled but respond well to having choices. Sequencing gives them autonomy within the necessary tasks.

strategies.name: Reset and Reconnect
script: This morning feels hard for both of us. Let's take a quick reset.
Give me a hug. We're going to figure this out together.
What would help your body feel more ready for the day?
We have a few minutes to make this morning feel better before we go.
strategies.mantra: Connection is more important than being on time. A good relationship with my child matters most.
strategies.why_it_works: When mornings go badly, taking a moment to reconnect can shift the entire dynamic and actually save time by reducing resistance.

parenting_scripts.title: Screen Time Battles
parenting_scripts.scenario: Child refuses to turn off devices, has meltdowns when screen time ends

strategies.name: Advance Warning
script: You have 5 more minutes of screen time, then it's time to turn it off.
I know it's hard to stop when you're having fun. Let's set a timer together.
When the timer goes off, screen time is done. What do you want to do next?
I'll help you turn it off when the timer rings.
strategies.mantra: Transitions are hard for kids. Advance notice helps their brain prepare for the change.
strategies.why_it_works: Sudden transitions from preferred activities trigger big emotions. Advance warning allows the brain time to mentally prepare for the change.

strategies.name: Validate and Redirect
script: You're so disappointed that screen time is over. That makes total sense.
It's hard when fun things have to end. You wish you could keep playing.
The screen is going away now, AND we can find something else fun to do.
What sounds interesting: building with blocks, going outside, or reading together?
strategies.mantra: Their disappointment is valid. I can acknowledge it while still maintaining the boundary.
strategies.why_it_works: Validating their disappointment while offering appealing alternatives helps shift their focus from what they're losing to what they're gaining.

strategies.name: Collaborative Solution
script: Screen time battles are hard for both of us. Let's solve this together.
What would help you remember when screen time is almost over?
How can we make turning off screens feel less terrible?
Let's come up with a plan that works for both of us.
strategies.mantra: Kids are more likely to follow rules they help create. Including them in problem-solving builds cooperation.
strategies.why_it_works: When children participate in creating solutions, they feel ownership and are more likely to cooperate. It builds problem-solving skills too.

emergency_quick_tips.public_meltdowns: Remember: Other people's opinions don't define your parenting. Focus on your child, not the stares.
emergency_quick_tips.safety_first: When behavior involves physical safety, act first and process emotions later.
emergency_quick_tips.when_to_take_breaks: If you feel yourself losing patience, it's okay to say 'I need a minute to calm down' and step away briefly.
emergency_quick_tips.professional_help: Seek support if tantrums increase in frequency/intensity, include self-harm, or if you feel overwhelmed consistently.

age_specific_notes.toddlers_1_3: Toddlers have big emotions but small coping skills. Extra patience and simple language work best.
age_specific_notes.preschool_3_5: Can understand more complex explanations but still need concrete choices and clear boundaries.
age_specific_notes.school_age_5_plus: Can participate in problem-solving but may still need help regulating intense emotions.
